figures.description: Average‑cost curve for Question 9. The vertical axis is cost and the horizontal axis is output. The curve is U‑shaped and labelled X–Y–Z. Segment XY slopes downward showing falling average cost as output rises; segment YZ slopes upward showing rising average cost at higher output levels.

Short‑run cost and revenue diagram for Questions 13 and 14. Price is on the vertical axis and quantity on the horizontal. The firm faces a horizontal demand curve \(MR = AR = P\). A U‑shaped average‑cost curve (AC) and an upward‑sloping marginal‑cost curve (MC) are drawn. The intersection of MC and MR gives the profit‑maximizing output; the area between price and AC at this output represents supernormal profit.

Demand and marginal‑revenue curves for Questions 20–22. The vertical axis is price \(P\); the horizontal axis is quantity \(Q\). A downward‑sloping demand curve is drawn with a steeper marginal‑revenue curve beneath it, both starting from price \(P_1\). Points \(P_2\), \(Q_1\) and \(Q_2\) mark different price–quantity combinations used to discuss elasticity and price discrimination.

Table for Question 18 showing output \(Q\) in tons, total cost of production \(TC\) in naira, and marginal cost \(MC\) per ton for a competitive firm. Candidates must determine the profit‑maximizing output when market price is fixed at \(P = \text{N}12\).

Value‑added table for Question 47. Four stages of production: maize farmer, flour miller, baker and shopkeeper. For each stage, the value of input purchased from the previous stage and the sale value of output are given. Total value added is the sum of \(\text{sale value} - \text{value of input}\) across all stages, which equals GDP by the value‑added approach.

instructions.text: In each of questions 1 to 50, choose the option that best answers the question or completes the statement.

questions.question: In a market economy, the question of what, how and for whom to produce are solved by the
questions.explanation: In a market economy, resource allocation decisions are coordinated by the **price mechanism** (demand and supply).

questions.question: Economic goods are termed scarce goods when they are

options.text: not available in sufficient quantities to satisfy all wants for them
not produced in sufficient quantities to satisfy the effective demand for them
of primary importance in satisfying the needs of a society

questions.explanation: In economics, a good is scarce when its supply is insufficient to satisfy **effective demand** (willingness and ability to pay).

questions.question: A school girl who needs a book and a mirror, each costing five naira, decides to purchase the book instead of the mirror since she cannot pay for the two at the same time. Determine the real cost of her choice.

options.text: The five naira she spent on the book

questions.explanation: The real (opportunity) cost of choosing the book is the **mirror forgone**.

questions.question: Macroeconomics is a study of economic science from the point of view of
questions.explanation: Macroeconomics deals with **aggregate variables** such as national income, employment and inflation for the entire economy.

questions.question: In combining inputs X and Y the entrepreneur obtains the maximum output from a given money outlay when
questions.explanation: Least‑cost (and hence maximum‑output for given spending) occurs when the **marginal product per naira is equalized**: \(\dfrac{MP_x}{P_x} = \dfrac{MP_y}{P_y}\).

questions.question: If units of a variable factor are increasingly added to a fixed factor and the marginal physical product keeps increasing, production is said to be taking place under condition of

options.text: increasing returns to the variable factor
constant returns to the variable factor

questions.explanation: As long as marginal product of the variable input is rising, there are **increasing returns to the variable factor**.

questions.question: At any given level of output, the total cost of a firm equals the

options.text: marginal cost plus the average cost
fixed cost less its variable cost
average cost multiplied by its output
economic costs multiplied by variable costs

questions.explanation: By definition, \(TC = AC \times Q\) at any output level.

questions.question: At any given level of output, a firm’s total variable cost equals

options.text: total cost less total fixed cost
average variable cost multiplied by marginal variable cost

questions.explanation: Total variable cost is **total cost minus total fixed cost**: \(TVC = TC - TFC\).

questions.question: Consider the average‑cost curve XYZ in figure Econ1991_AC_XYZ. Segment XY shows that as output increases the average cost declines. However, this decline cannot continue indefinitely because of
questions.explanation: The eventual upward slope of the long‑run average‑cost curve (segment YZ) is due to **diseconomies of scale** such as managerial inefficiency and coordination problems. The precise wording of option A in the scan is unclear, so the official key cannot be stated with certainty.

questions.question: If the price of a ball‑point pen falls from N1.00 to N0.60 and the quantity demanded increases from 200 to 300, the price elasticity of demand (using the arc formula) is equal to
questions.explanation: Using the arc elasticity formula: \(E_d = \dfrac{\Delta Q}{\Delta P} \times \dfrac{P_1 + P_2}{Q_1 + Q_2} = \dfrac{100}{-0.4} \times \dfrac{1.0 + 0.6}{200 + 300} \approx -0.8\). In absolute value, elasticity is **0.80** (inelastic).

questions.question: If a society is operating on the production possibility curve, this implies that the resources are
questions.explanation: Points on the PPC represent combinations where **all resources are fully and efficiently employed**.

questions.question: A market is in disequilibrium if

options.text: the quantity purchased is greater than the quantity sold
the quantity sold differs from the quantity purchased
at a lower price, a larger quantity is sold
the quantity demanded differs from the quantity supplied

questions.explanation: Market equilibrium requires \(Q_d = Q_s\). If **quantity demanded differs from quantity supplied**, the market is in disequilibrium.

questions.question: Using the cost–revenue diagram in figure Econ1991_PerfComp_ShortRun, the excess profit made by the firm in the short run is represented by the area
questions.explanation: In a perfectly competitive firm earning supernormal profit, the excess profit area is the rectangle between the price line \(P\) and the average‑cost curve at the equilibrium output. The exact labelled area cannot be identified reliably from the small scan.

questions.question: From the same diagram (figure Econ1991_PerfComp_ShortRun), the long‑run equilibrium price and quantity for the firm are respectively
questions.explanation: In long‑run equilibrium under perfect competition, price equals minimum average cost: \(P = MC = AC_{\min}\). The scan does not clearly show which letters correspond to this point.

questions.question: The cross‑elasticity of demand between complementary goods is
questions.explanation: For complements, \(E_{xy} < 0\): an increase in the price of one good reduces demand for the other.

questions.question: Resources are efficiently allocated when production takes place at that output where price equals
questions.explanation: Allocative efficiency in a competitive market requires \(P = MC\).

questions.question: Comparison of the price and output decisions of a perfectly competitive firm with those of a monopolist shows that the

options.text: monopolist charges a lower price than the perfect competitor
perfect competitor charges a lower price and produces a larger output than the monopolist
perfect competitor produces a smaller output than the monopolist
monopolist charges a lower price and produces a larger output than the perfect competitor

questions.explanation: Given the same cost and demand conditions, monopoly **restricts output and charges a higher price** than perfect competition; thus the competitive firm has lower price and higher output.

questions.question: Using the table in figure Econ1991_Profit_Table, which shows output (Q), total cost (TC) and marginal cost (MC) for a firm in a competitive market with price fixed at \(P = \text{N}12\), what is the maximum profit the firm can make?
questions.explanation: Profit at each output is \(\pi = P \times Q - TC\). The firm should choose the output where \(P\) is closest to \(MC\) from below and profit is highest. Exact calculation requires precise TC/MC values, which are not fully legible in the scan.

questions.question: In a perfectly competitive market, the firm is in long‑run equilibrium at the output where
questions.explanation: In long‑run competitive equilibrium, \(P = MC = AC\) and **AC is at its minimum**; firms earn only normal profit.

questions.question: With reference to figure Econ1991_Monopoly_Demand_MR, the firm portrayed is selling in

options.text: a market in which demand is elastic at all prices
a market in which companies produce homogeneous commodities

questions.explanation: The downward‑sloping demand and separate marginal‑revenue curve indicate **imperfect competition** (e.g. monopoly, monopolistic competition).

questions.question: Using the same diagram (figure Econ1991_Monopoly_Demand_MR), demand is relatively inelastic in the

options.text: lower portion of the demand curve below the midpoint
upper portion of the demand curve above the midpoint
entire length of the demand curve

questions.explanation: For a straight‑line demand curve, elasticity is greater than 1 above the midpoint, equal to 1 at the midpoint and less than 1 below it. The exact labels (P2, Q1, Q2) are not legible enough to match with the options.

questions.question: Which of the following statements must hold if price discrimination is to be possible?

options.text: Elasticities in the various markets must not differ
The seller must not recognise differences among buyers
The markets must not be separated but integrated
The markets should be separable and resale between them must be impossible

questions.explanation: Price discrimination requires that markets can be **segmented** and that **arbitrage (resale) is prevented**; otherwise buyers in high‑price markets would switch to low‑price markets.

questions.question: The ordinary partner in a partnership

options.text: takes no active part in management of the business
has limited liability in case of business failure
has unlimited liability in case of business failure
cannot be sued personally on matters relating to the business

questions.explanation: An ordinary (general) partner **takes part in management** and has **unlimited liability**.

questions.question: A possible factor which limits the extent of growth of a firm is the

options.text: unwillingness to share ownership and control

questions.explanation: If the owner is **unwilling to admit new partners or shareholders**, capital is limited and growth is constrained.

questions.question: One of the most outstanding disadvantages of co‑operative societies as business organizations is that

options.text: true spirit of co‑operation is marred by delegated authority
membership interest is centred on sharing of essential commodities

questions.explanation: A common weakness of co‑operatives is **inadequate capital**, because members usually contribute small sums.

questions.question: A disadvantage of a joint‑stock company is

options.text: loss of controlling interest by small shareholders

questions.explanation: In joint‑stock companies, ownership is widely dispersed and original owners may **lose effective control** to professional managers or majority shareholders.

questions.question: A characteristic of a debenture is that

options.text: its yield is based on profits
its yield is a fixed rate of interest
there is a voting right when interest is paid

questions.explanation: A debenture is a long‑term loan to a company that earns a **fixed rate of interest**, regardless of profits.

questions.question: Industries tend to be located closer to market centres than to the sources of raw materials if the

options.text: products are relatively cheap to transport to market centres
products are relatively more expensive to transport than the major raw materials
raw materials can also be imported

questions.explanation: When finished products are **more costly to transport** than raw materials, firms minimize cost by locating near the **market**.

questions.question: One disadvantage of trade by barter is that

options.text: people are happier when they exchange the same quantities of goods through money rather than by barter
the person wishing to buy good X may not have good Y which is what the other person wants
one person must always be cheated when trade takes place by barter
it increases the initial cost of producing goods

questions.explanation: Barter requires a **double coincidence of wants**; often this condition is not met, making trade difficult.

questions.question: One of the functions of Development Banks is to

options.text: mint money for the development of the economy
provide short‑term loans to commercial banks
provide medium‑ and long‑term finance for development of the banking system
provide medium‑ and long‑term finance for the development of the economy

questions.explanation: Development banks specialize in **medium‑ and long‑term financing of development projects**.

questions.question: To perform its function as a store of wealth and standard for deferred payment, money must be

options.text: spent more on capital goods than on consumer goods

questions.explanation: If money’s value fluctuates widely, it cannot effectively serve as a **store of value** or **standard for deferred payments**; stability is essential.

questions.question: Fiduciary issue is that part of

options.text: the issue of notes backed entirely by gold
a country’s currency which is not negotiable
the issue of notes not backed by gold

questions.explanation: The **fiduciary issue** is the portion of the note issue that is **not backed by gold or foreign exchange reserves**, relying instead on the issuer’s trustworthiness.

questions.question: An effect of inflation is that it

options.text: favours debtors at the expense of creditors
increases the real income of salary earners
increases the value of a country’s exports

questions.explanation: With unexpected inflation, debts are repaid in money of **reduced purchasing power**, so **debtors gain and creditors lose**.

questions.question: Banks aid economic expansion and development by

options.text: being very strict in lending policies

questions.explanation: By **mobilizing savings and channelling them into productive investment**, banks promote economic growth.

questions.question: The term 'stock of capital' means

options.text: amount of money necessary to start a business
total amount receivable by all factors of production
amount of equipment, plant and inventory existing at a time
total amount available for economic development

questions.explanation: The capital stock is the **existing quantity of physical capital** (machines, buildings, inventories) at a point in time.

questions.question: A tax that takes an increasing fraction of income as income goes down is called
questions.explanation: In a **regressive tax**, lower‑income earners pay a **higher proportion** of their income in tax.

questions.question: Budget deficit is the amount by which
questions.explanation: A **budget deficit** occurs when government **expenditure is greater than revenue** in a fiscal year.

questions.question: The average tax rate is defined as

options.text: total tax rate less the marginal tax rate
the tax rate which applies to additional value of income
the ratio of total taxes paid to total income
marginal tax rate for being progressive

questions.explanation: Average tax rate \(= \dfrac{\text{total tax paid}}{\text{total income}}\).

questions.question: Personal distribution of income implies

options.text: how income is distributed among specific households or spending units
the distribution of income according to basic resource classes
dividing income between personal taxes, consumption expenditure and savings

questions.explanation: Personal distribution concerns **how national income is shared among individuals or households**, not among factors.

questions.question: One of the advantages of international trade is that it

options.text: promotes self‑reliance and satisfaction with only what can be produced internally

questions.explanation: By allowing specialization according to comparative advantage, international trade **raises total world output**.

questions.question: There is an improvement in the terms of trade of a country if

options.text: a large quantity of exports is given up to obtain a unit of imports
the volume of exports is greater than the volume of imports
a smaller quantity of exports is given up to obtain a unit of imports
the value of exports is greater than the value of imports

questions.explanation: Improved terms of trade mean a rise in the ratio \(P_X / P_M\): each unit of exports now buys **more imports**, so fewer exports are given up per unit of imports.

questions.question: Under flexible exchange rates, a balance‑of‑payments deficit could be corrected by

options.text: appreciation of other currencies (i.e. depreciation of the home currency)

questions.explanation: With flexible rates, a **depreciation of the home currency** (equivalent to appreciation of others) makes exports cheaper and imports dearer, helping to correct a deficit.

questions.question: The higher the dependency ratio, the

options.text: larger the proportion of the employed relative to the unemployed
smaller the proportion of the active labour force relative to the inactive population
smaller the number of the non‑working age groups relative to the active labour force

questions.explanation: A high dependency ratio means **more dependants (young and old) relative to working‑age people**, i.e. a smaller active labour force proportion.

questions.question: The age distribution of a country’s population is of economic importance because it affects the
questions.explanation: Different age groups have different consumption needs; thus age structure strongly influences the **pattern of expenditure** in the economy.

questions.question: It is important to measure the national income of a country because

options.text: it is a major determinant of the standard of living
it reveals all areas of development like pollution and congestion
it indicates the distribution of citizens’ savings in foreign banks
its size determines the extent of political stability

questions.explanation: Per capita national income is a widely used indicator of **material standard of living**.

questions.question: Gross Domestic Product is defined as the total value of

options.text: all final goods and services produced in a country during the year
all assets of a country in a particular year
exports net of total value of imports

questions.explanation: GDP is the **market value of all final goods and services produced within a country’s borders in a given period**.

questions.question: Using the value‑added table in figure Econ1991_GDP_ValueAdded, the value of total output in the economy using the value‑added approach is
questions.explanation: Value added at each stage is \(\text{sale value} - \text{value of input}\). Summing across the four stages gives total value added of **N200**, which equals GDP by the value‑added method.

questions.question: If W stands for wages/salaries, P for profit, R for rent, I for interest and Z for net income from land and real estate, then national income is
questions.explanation: By the income approach, national income at factor cost is the **sum of all factor incomes**: \(W + P + R + I + \text{(net other factor incomes)}\). The exact symbols and wording in the options are blurred in the scan, so the official answer cannot be stated with confidence.

questions.question: In the national income and output accounts, double counting will occur if

options.text: only intermediate goods are counted once
only intermediate and final goods are counted
the values of intermediate goods and services are added together with the values of final goods and services

questions.explanation: Counting both intermediate goods and the final goods that embody them would **count the same value more than once**, i.e. double counting.

questions.question: A major obstacle to economic development is
questions.explanation: Low productivity caused by a **poor attitude to work** and weak work ethic can seriously hinder economic development.
